abstract.p: Jonathan Green letter on June 24 article holds computer science research is being done mainly by software companies, not universities

block.p: You write (front page, June 25) that an increasing number of computer science professors and students are leaving universities to pursue opportunities in the software industry, raising fear among experts that ''fundamental research will decline and that the next generation of American computer scientists will be stunted.''

You write (front page, June 25) that an increasing number of computer science professors and students are leaving universities to pursue opportunities in the software industry, raising fear among experts that ''fundamental research will decline and that the next generation of American computer scientists will be stunted.''

Computer science is an applied field, and fundamental research these days is done primarily by software companies, not universities. Java, the hottest language around, was invented by Sun Microsystems, not M.I.T. As long as there is strong demand for software development, there will be strong demand for computer science training. If universities can't keep up with the latest languages, companies will provide this training themselves.
